title: NLL diagnostics should only name lifetimes when there is more than one lifetime in the error.

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
The nll diagnostics always name the lifetimes (e.g. `1) even when there is only one lifetime.
Assigning a name to something is an extra mental burden, so it would be a lot easier to read if we didnt do that when there is only one lifetime in the error.

There is already a unittest showing the issue:
https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/130b9e9e3b058e76e43788fac67538c064fc8a97/src/test/ui/issues/issue-46983.rs#L1-L6

The current output without NLL enabled (migrate) is:
https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/130b9e9e3b058e76e43788fac67538c064fc8a97/src/test/ui/issues/issue-46983.stderr#L1-L11

The current output with NLL enabled is:
https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/130b9e9e3b058e76e43788fac67538c064fc8a97/src/test/ui/issues/issue-46983.nll.stderr#L1-L10

Ideally the NLL output should look like:
```
error: lifetime may not live long enough
  --> $DIR/issue-46983.rs:2:5
   |
LL | fn foo(x: &u32) -> &'static u32 {
   |           - the lifetime of this reference ...
LL |     &*x
   |     ^^^ ... is required to be `static here due to the function returning 'static

error: aborting due to previous error
```
I'm not really happy with this desired output, but not really sure how to fix it :/
